page.lettertext:
fol.181r
[B]
elgia 1592 23 Aprill to my L Trea
s
May it please yo
r
good L. I have bin infor-
med very lately by a friend of good credit and
countenance, and one
at doth assure me of the
truth of his report, that w
t
in this moneth there
came a secret messenger to
Count Maurice
, w
th
a
letter of credence from
e
D. of Parma
. The
party was knowen to
e autor of this advertism
t
an
Utrecht
man borne, and very well quali-
fied. Assoone as he came hither he addressed him-
self to
M
r
Sonsfielde
, one
at hath governed the
Count in all his youth, and is continually neere
about him:
e self same party to whome
Mons
r
Bilandt
, before his comming to
e Hage, writte a
letter of persuasion to move him to favo
r
the
mater of
his message
pacificati
o
. By this gentlemans meanes
the Count was informed of
e messengers comming
and gave him leave to doe his message, but in
e
presence of some others, w
ch
were
Mons
r
de Fauma
who is Governo
r
of
Hoesden,
M
r
Barnevelt
, and
e said M
r
Sonsfilde. After
at
e messenger
had exhibited his credence he saluted
e Count
in
e name of
e Duke, w
t
very honorable com-
plements, declaring his desire to advance his
estate, and wishing therupon
at he would harken
to a Treaty: w
ch
in case he would admitte, and
persuade
e contrey to
e like, suche conditions
should be graunted as he himself would re-
quire. For
howsoever
although
e
King of Spaine
might
should
refuse to yelde unto them, he had waies enough
to force him: w
ch
he should see him put in pra-
tise. The Count would make no ans-
ear to this message of
e party, but dismissed
him presently, and after some time of his aboade
in this place gave him licence to be gone.
He went from hens to Utrecht, where assoone as he
arrived M
r
Barnevelt had written to the
fol.181v
Officers of the towne, to examine him strictly about his co
[ming]
to that place. Howbeit w
t
in a day or two after, he writt
[.]
againe to discharge him. This is all
at
e partie coulde
[tell]
me of this matter: w
ch
he assured me was true. But for
[any other]
other circumstaunce, wether there passed any more between
[the]
Duke and the Count ether after or before, he was utterly
[ignorant]
w
ch
I thought very fitte to advertise yo
r
L.
and so I take
[my]
humble leave. A
p
23
1592
